Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I sat on the lifeguard chair, scanning the pool, my whistle ready. My stepdad and mom were at the edge, chatting quietly, their faces drawn and tired. Lately, they’d been arguing more, and I knew they needed me—someone to talk to, someone to lean on. I wanted to go over, offer a hug, maybe just sit with them for a while. But as I watched, a group of kids slipped into the shallow end, giggling, no adult in sight. My training kicked in: I had to enforce the rules, keep everyone safe, no exceptions. My heart twisted. If I left my post, even for a minute, I’d be letting down the swimmers and breaking the trust my boss had in me. But if I stayed, I’d be ignoring my parents when they needed me most. The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I felt torn, unable to be the step-child my family needed and the lifeguard my job demanded—all at the same time.
